name: NPR
text:
President Trump won the 2016 election, in which 25% of ballots were cast by mail. By railing against absentee voting, "you potentially jeopardize your own interest," says Tom Ridge, Pennsylvania's former Republican governor.
https://t.co/hFML9laXRP

name: NPR
text:
Phoenix has joined several cities across Arizona requiring residents to wear masks in public spaces amid a sharp spike in COVID-19 cases.

Additionally, businesses have the right to refuse service to anyone who doesn't comply with the order.
https://t.co/9RtllETYZZ

name: NPR
text: The Pentagon is lifting travel restrictions for military personnel in 46 states  — despite a rise in new coronavirus infections in 23 of those states.  https://t.co/OscVsKKz2h

name: NPR
text: AMC Theaters now says it will require face coverings for customers in all of its theaters reopening in July. The change came after an outcry against the company for not making it a mandate in the first place. https://t.co/NJRRG4F9Nx

name: NPR
text:
Courts are using Zoom calls to hold eviction hearings amid the pandemic. 

For some, the inability to connect to the call may not just be the loss of basic rights — but also the "difference between housing and homelessness."
https://t.co/SpyLrkjVb4

name: NPR
text:
Berman said in his own statement: "I have not resigned, I have no intention of resigning."

He said he intends to see that his office's cases "continue unimpeded." https://t.co/RucjtBH9cp

name: NPR
text: While Geoffrey Berman pushes back against leaving his post as U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Attorney General Barr's press release indicated that President Trump has already appointed an interim replacement. https://t.co/aEbnhbXUWE

name: NPR
text:
Several Major League Baseball and National Hockey League teams have closed their facilities in Florida after players tested positive for COVID-19. 
https://t.co/WLo9lshs5X

name: NPR
text: In “Democracy In One Book Or Less,” David Litt, former speechwriter to President Obama, debunks myths about our founders, pointing up false narratives and warped historical perceptions. https://t.co/8x27Mmfajz

name: NPR
text:
Teyana Taylor's third musical project, simply titled “The Album,” is a sprawling work of 23 tracks that sends a clear message: She's done compromising her creative vision. 
https://t.co/yNfqsntuKN

name: NPR
text: “I am just so happy that I have lived long enough to witness this moment,” activist Angela Davis tells @hereandnow. “And I think that I see myself as witnessing this moment for all of those who lost their lives in the struggle over the decades.” https://t.co/Oh46HJAsYW

name: NPR
text:
The bus from "Into The Wild" is gone, lifted by a helicopter out of Alaska's Denali National Park. 

The state fielded 15 bus-related search and rescue operations by the state between 2009 and 2017. Hikers drowned in 2010 and 2019. 

Via @alaskapublic https://t.co/Qar86j6mLF

name: NPR
text:
No single lineage can contain the magic of New Orleans music.

But one essential thread is the legacy of queer people — from Bobby Marchan to Big Freedia — who steered the sounds and the scenes.
https://t.co/hpN7SJphqp

name: NPR
text:
These NYC students say misinformation about COVID-19 led to hurtful, racist comments from their peers: "They were basically saying how we have coronavirus because we are Chinese." 

So, they made a podcast to set the facts straight — and call out racism.
https://t.co/Q5LYSy9jjV
